comments.commentBody: My wife and I have done well. Our kids went to college and we just paid off the 18g interest plus much more principal on college loans. I am a union man fortunate to have an annuity fund and a pension. Social Security helps too. All because my union brothers and sisters were allowed to organize and fight for fair packages. I vote democratic in every election. My lot is set, Now I'm voting to try to get some fairness for the younger workers following me. Organize, do your job the union way, better than others, and command pay and benefits commensurate to your skill and work ethic.
And you could do even better if you could back date purchase times to the market lows, etc..  Why can't they all be CEOs?
Yeah we don't want government union workers! We want low wage workers!  We don't want a middle class in the USA!
Well, how come every other industrialized nation on earth can manage health care for all their citizens - -but USA cannot?
I'm a boomer and don't blame me for Reagan!!!!!!  He was voted in by the silent generation.
I am so tired of being lumped into "this generation". I support Bernie Sanders. What is "this generation" about that, other than the fact Bernie fits this demo !?!
It's too bad this very same generation has voted away the post war social contract, and for people like Reagan.

SECOND TIME posting this.

Nothing changes? Really?

Pensions are gone. The Social Security Trust Fund has been looted to the tune of a couple of trillion. Corporations contribute some 8% to the federal treasury, versus 25% in the the 1950s. The tax rate on the highest earners is just a third above the rate in the 1950s. Secretaries for Fortune 400 CEOs pay a higher tax rate than their bosses. And I expect that you pay a higher rate than Mitt Romney.

College debt now exceeds all the credit card debt in the country. The great public university systems, once free or low cost, are no longer funded. (As Reagan's education secretary said when he was governor, "We can't have an educated proletariat" - they got that one right.) Oh, yes, union membership (some 25%-30% of the workforce in the 1950s) has dropped to some 8% of workers.

Practicing the "boring wisdom of the ages" may put one in a better economic position that one's cohorts who don't, but with salaried workers and small businesspeople receiving smaller and smaller pieces of the economic pie, it is scant protection against bad luck, bad health, and the bad faith of the ruling class.

On target 100% - I, SWRF70ish, grew up hearing about living during the Depression from my parents it frightened me so I studied, worked and saved.  8 yrs before I wanted to retire my advisor strongly suggested that I save and contribute an additional 20% (gasp!) of my take home pay to my 401K which I did. I worked 2 more years until 67.5 yrs. Live on less and do, enjoy & love more.

This has struck a nerve, but I know many people in our basic situation. Does it apply to the younger generation? I'll address that, but if baby boomers couldn't invest and save and make prudent personal and financial decisions, who could?

My dad (born 1922) died at 79; never retired because he loved his profession. He and my mom built financial security, and he hadn't needed to work for years. My grandfather (born 1895) retired at 65 in 1960 (he was an adult during the Depression). He lived another 17 years and my grandmother lived 34 years after that retirement, with strong financial security.

We have 5 children, mostly middle aged now, inasmuch as we had all of them before 30. They and/or their spouses are well employed.

I could go on. But ask yourself this: how does a man raise a family in the Depression, retire in 1960, and have enough to have a comfortable retirement for himself for 17 years and his wife for 34 years, until she died at 96? That should be impossible, right? (He built and owned a small local heating business.)

The article is accurate, and it's good to see something sensible on the subject at last. (I'm 67, by the way, still working full-time because I enjoy work.)

There are no miracles involved. Save and invest regularly throughout your career, stay married to the same person, pay off your mortgage on time or ahead of time, and so on. It's just the boring wisdom of the ages.

Every worthwhile investment in this life is a long-term investment, both the financial ones and the personal ones. Hold on to these investments; always take the long view. Financial security comes; it takes decades, though. Your parents knew it. Your grandparents knew it. Nothing changes; not really.

This is a very sneaky way of saying you don't think the government or any organization should offer a pension, which the people in this article are clearly benefitting from. I suppose with all the savings to the taxpayers a tax cut-- for the 1%-- might be in order?? Disgraceful
Yes we understand many people have it worse.

The average European retiree has a public pension, but not a lot of assets. Big deal.

Talk to a Brit sometimes about their old-age pension system, and compare it with Social Security. They are usually shocked. They suppose their system is better, and are floored when they find out the truth about the level of our benefits. Especially when they find out that people who have worked all their lives receive more than those who have always been on the dole. Ask them what they think about the fairness of their system!

Seniors are now "special interests"? And low wage workers are "special interests"? And young people with student loan debt are "special interests"?
Who is this "average American" who the Democrats don't care about?

"I am glad to know a segment of my generation has parlayed pensions, Social Security, and home equity or investments into a comfortable retirement. Another segment never earned enough for a significant Social Security check, does not receive pensions, watched home equity vanish in 2008..."

That close to or into retirement and losing home equity? Someone was doubling down.
If you have saved and invested all of your life, you have a lot more than a quarter-million bucks.

I totally agree. It gets me sooo mad when conservatives attack unions, which are the very best guarantor of a good life for the worker. I do think the pendulum has begun to swing the other way though. I looks like Reaganism is starting to sputter and government as the people's friend is going to make a comeback.
P.S. Stand with your union and your union will stand with you.
Pensions could actually come back if people joined unions again and voted out Koch - owned politicians like Scott Walker. Nothing is set in stone.

I did not vote for Reagan. It's the 30-somethings who cooked up the financial wizardry that led to the last economic debacle.

Didn't your parents help put you through college? Didn't you grow up in a nice house in a nice neighborhood?

When my children get in trouble (we all do), they come to us -- and we help. Don't your parents help you when you need help?
My 101 year old father was the same.

Pensions could only work if people lived to an average age of about 72. That's why it worked for our parents. But now the average life expectancy is 82 for men and 86 for women. Pensions for this population would go bankrupt if they were funded they way they were a generation ago - or if they are funded at the level required for current life expectancy, the companies that fund them would go bankrupt. Something has to give.

Pensions would be of little use to most American workers because they don't spend enough time with one employer to fully vest in that pension plan.  The days of folks working for the same company for 30 years are gone.  Defined contribution plans provide the portability employees need when changing jobs so often.  I had five "real" jobs with different companies by the time I was in my early 40s.  I'm sure glad for the generous 401K matches and tax deductions I received along the way.

All retirement systems have to be fully funded. The huge problems that developed with corporate and public pensions is that they were not fully funded. It is perfectly possible to have a fully-funded program; the State of Washington's PERS II, instituted by pension reform in the late 1970s, is totally actuarially sound. It provides very good benefits. It has two big features: it is paid for, by employee and employer contributions, and you can't draw it until age 65. This model could be adopted everywhere if there is the political will.

How much money do you think needs to be in the plan to support your pension? Probably at least the $600,000 you are talking about. So there's nothing startling about saying that a 401K would have to have that kind of money in it to be equivalent. The whole point is that any real plan, public or private, requires the same thing-- the money must be contributed to the plan!

That means, as always, is that it can't be spent now. In other words, savings and investments-- over a whole working life.

The loss of pensions for most Americans will be a huge negative factor in future retirees' lives.  401Ks are not an adequate replacement.  To get the benefits I now receive from my own pension (I retired six years ago), I would have had to accumulate over $600,000 in a 401K.  We need a new movement to compel corporations to reinstate pensions -- or face a growing poverty rate among elderly Americans.

The Democratic Party would govern securely in this country if they had stuck to their economic programs.

Alas, they long ago became the party of "cultural change". People don't live by bread alone, but they forgot that. Folks don't just vote they pocketbooks; this has been realized for decades, but it doesn't change the Democratic trajectory....

Not everyone that is retired belonged to a union.

Insofar as the government programs go, well keep the focus on the working class. No more Model Cities experiments. Some of that aversion to government programs out there is due to the fact that when a government program fails and produces disastrous results the participants are tossed like n old Petri dish.

I live in what was a very upscale subdivision just North but with in the Perimeter of Atlanta built from 1960-1965. The houses were 2,500 SF brick ranches to 3,500 SF 2 story brick homes. Mine is a 3,300 2 story built in 1965 with a 20x40 pool, about 1/2 had pools. The neighborhood looked like it was Out of the movies "the Help" . My house cost $32,500 originally.

The man across the street is original from 1961. First his 51 year old son moved in to help after his divorce. Then his son, now a younger son. Recently, the man's 60 year old son moved in because he has COPD and can no longer work. Then I found out the truth that 51 year old son didn't just move in with his boys to care for Dad since Mom passed away about 5 years ago, but because his business failed. Then one of the kids blurted out that the other uncle may have to move in as well because he has a health condition.

The 51 year old had told me they had attended one of the two top private high schools in Atlanta as Boys. The tuition at the school is now in the mid $20's he was lamenting about not wanting to send his son to the public high school.

So yes Dad's house is paid for. Dad has Social security and a Pension, along with an old Mercedes citing in the driveway. I don't think in his mid 80's he imagined supporting 50-60 year old sons and two teen boys. He also just paid to have a basement bathroom renovated to accomadate the household additions.

Middle class wealth started to drop in the early to mid 1970's. The writing was on the wall if anyone wanted to pay attention.
But mentioning Reagan does make for a better polemic.

Not the "Greatest Generation," Socrates?  I never thought so. They were oppressive in the 60s, and very pro-Vietnam war, simply because they happened to fight in the only war in the last century and a half that could in any sense be called justified. Fifties conformists.

Well, no, not "just like". Social Security's become a larger and larger bite from the paycheck as number of old people, proportionally, has grown. Many more people now must work as self-employed and independent contractors, too, leaving them with a 15% bite out of income for FICA alone, before we even talk about income tax or the health insurance you used to take for granted or the whopping, eternal student loan payments you didn't have.

I understand you're worried about your next 30 years, but you may need to look to the wealthy rather than those younger than you with empty pockets.
Ray, You hit on a great point. So many people don't plan for the future. Small steps over time can lead to a good outcome.

Hey, a deal's a deal. Social Security is not a tax, it's an income program that we all pay into and we all get benefits from. Younger people are just going to have to do whatever they need to, I order to carry their share of the responsibility, just like workers before them.

I'm 55, started at the bottom and had a great career. I never had a DB plan, but saved as much as I could, in my 401(k)s. I paid off my house and also bought and rehabbed a couple of rental houses. I'm totally set for retirement in a few years, I just need the Gen X'ers and Millenials to make sure and pay my Social Security, just like I paid for the generations before me.

While I support a return to the 65 retirement age, like so many others, if you insist that you can just "raise the payroll tax limits" to fund SS -- then you do not understand the basic premise of SS.

It is, for most people, a "pay as you go" system where you receive in retirement a percentage of your contributions & income. It is NOT simply an "old age pensioner's tax" -- if it was, it would not be popular nor as secure as it is. FDR knew this very well.

If you tax 100% of the income of the super rich, you would need to PAY OUT the same amounts to them in retirement -- and someone like Bill Gates would be getting $5 million a month (since he earns billions each year).

Also the SS system would entirely lose all support among anyone earning over $116K a year -- since they would pay into the system, but never be allowed to get back what they put in (I presume, unless you approve of sending billionaires checks for millions). Today, the maximum payout is something like $2900 a month, no matter how much you earn, because of the cut off. You'd be destroying that part of the system.

No -- sadly -- if you want to increase the financial assets of SS, you have to raise the payroll RATE, not the cap. Meaning we all must pay MORE. There is no way to simply "soak the rich".

No it was Nixon in 1972 that actually cut off pell grants and other federal aid to colleges; California was the only state were, if you were a resident, the tuition was free....And you did know that Reagan, as your "out of work" actor was actually President of one of the largest unions in California (at least clout-wise), the Screen Actor's Guild, right?

@Realist:  Speak for yourself.  I graduated owing $10,000 in student loans (that was AFTER working during college/grad school & getting some scholarships).  I spent 10 years paying off those loans in full.  Loan repayment was a major item in my limited budget.  (And I was NOT living at home with my parents!)

Reagan was never unemployed.  Besides movies, he did a lot of television and was the GE spokesperson.  I don't know if he ended free tuition, but he did end the USSR.  Sadly, you are not the only one here obsessed with Reagan.

You can also add "no college debt." When I went to UCLA 1964-1968 it was free except for a reg fee of $120.50 per semester which became $80.50 per quarter. I'm pretty sure tuition started under Reagan (as a way to punish those "spoiled" anti-Vietnam War protesters).
P.S. Reagan invoked the 11th commandment because HE didn't want to be criticized during the primary by George Christopher (who was mayor of San Francisco whereas Reagan was an out-of-work actor being supported by a bunch of anti-tax rich guys - his "kitchen cabinet").
You mean, "just like the lack of dental benefits that exists in the much-admired (by lefties) Canadian single payer health insurance"?
